briefdescription.para: change the right for a file or a folder

parameterdescription.para: : path of the file or the folder, can be in all supported protocols (lfn, srm, file, guid,..)
: right to configure

simplesect.para: return 0 if success else -1 and errno is set, call gfal_posix_check_error() to check it

briefdescription.para: change the name or location of a file oldpath and newpath need to be on the same plugin this functions work only with plugins (lfc ) and local files

parameterdescription.para: : the old path of the file, can be in supported protocols but need to be in the same adress space than newpath
: the new path of the file, can be in supported protocols (lfn, srm, file, guid,..)

simplesect.para: : return 0 if success, else -1 and errno / gfal_posix_check_error()

briefdescription.para: informations about a file These functions return information about a file. No permissions are required on the file itself, but — in the case of stat() and lstat() — execute (search) permission is required on all of the directories in path that lead to the file.

parameterdescription.para: : path of the file, can be in supported protocols (lfn, srm, file, guid,..)
: pointer to an allocated struct stat

simplesect.para: return 0 if success else -1 and errno is set, call gfal_posix_check_error() to check it

briefdescription.para: gfal_lstat is identical to gfal_stat except for symbolic links. In this case, the link itself is statted and not followed.
test access to the given file

parameterdescription.para: path of the file to access, can be in supported protocols (lfn, srm, file, guid,..)
access mode to check (R_OK, W_OK, X_OK or F_OK)

simplesect.para: This routine return 0 if the operation was successful, or -1 if error occured and errno is set, call gfal_posix_check_error() to check it.

briefdescription.para: make a new name for a file

detaileddescription.para:
similar to the POSIX call symlink . symlink() creates a symbolic link named newpath which contains the string oldpath.
newpath
: path of the link, can be in supported protocols but need to be in the same adress space than newpath
oldpath
: path of the linked file, can be in supported protocols (lfn, srm, file, guid,..)
0 if success else -1. if failure, errno is set, you can call gfal_posix_check_error() for a more complete description.

briefdescription.para: create a new file or truncate an existing one similar to the POSIX call creat opens a file according to the value of flags.

parameterdescription.para: : url of the filename to create, can be in supported protocols (lfn, srm, file, guid,..)
: is used only if the file is created.

simplesect.para: return the file descriptor or -1 if errno is set call gfal_posix_check_error() to check it

briefdescription.para: open a file similar to the POSIX call open opens a file according to the value of flags.

parameterdescription.para: : url of the filename to open. can be in supported protocols (lfn, srm, file, guid,..)

: same flag supported value is built by OR’ing the bits defined in <fcntl.h> but one and only one of the first three flags below must be used O_RDONLY open for reading only O_WRONLY open for writing only O_RDWR open for reading and writing O_CREAT If the file exists already and O_EXCL is also set, gfal_open will fail O_LARGEFILE allows files whose sizes cannot be represented in 31 bits to be opened
is used only if the file is created.

simplesect.para: return the file descriptor or -1 if errno is set call gfal_posix_check_error() to check it

briefdescription.para: set position in a file

detaileddescription.para: similar to the POSIX call lseek gfal_lseek positions/repositions to offset the file associated with the descriptor fd generated by a previous gfal_open. whence indicates how to interpret the offset value:
SEEK_SET The offset is set from beginning of file.
SEEK_CUR The offset is added to current position.

SEEK_END The offset is added to current file size.
fd
: file descriptor to lseek
offset :
offset in byte
whence :
flag
This routine returns the actual offset from the beginning of the file if the operation was successful or -1 if the operation failed. In the latter case, errno is set appropriately, you can call gfal_posix_check_error() for a more complete description.

briefdescription.para: close a file similar to the POSIX call close closes the file whose descriptor fd is the one returned by gfal_open.

parameterdescription.para: : descriptor or the file given by gfal_open

simplesect.para: This routine returns 0 if the operation was successful or -1 if the operation failed. In the latter case, errno is set appropriately

briefdescription.para: read a file similar to the POSIX call read gfal_read reads up to size bytes from the file descriptor fd into the buffer pointed by buff

parameterdescription.para: file descriptor
buffer of the data to read
size of the data read in bytes

simplesect.para: number of byte read or -1 if error, errno is set call gfal_posix_check_error() to check it

briefdescription.para: write a file similar to the POSIX call write gfal_write writes size bytes from the buffer pointed by buff to the file descriptor fd.

parameterdescription.para: file descriptor
buffer of the data to write
size of the data write in bytes

simplesect.para: number of byte write or -1 if error, errno is set call gfal_posix_check_error() to check it

memberdef.argsstring: (const char *path, const char *name, void *value, size_t size)
memberdef.name: gfal_getxattr

briefdescription.para: retrieve an extended attribute value

detaileddescription.para:
similar to the getxattr call of the libattr gfal_getxattr retrieves an extended value for an url in a supported protocol. The extended attributes are use for the advanced file operations ( like set/get replicas, grid status, comments, etc... )
path
: path of the file/dir, can be in supported protocols (lfn, srm, file, guid,..)
name :
name of the attribute to get
value :
pointer to buffer to get the value
size
: size of the buffer
return the size of the data returned, or -1 if error. In this case, errno is set and you can call gfal_posix_check_error() for a more complete description.

briefdescription.para: list all extended attributes

detaileddescription.para: similar to listxattr standard call of libattr gfal_listxattr list all extended atributes associated with a file The extended attributes are use for the advanced file operations ( like set/get replicas, grid status, comments, etc... )

parameterdescription.para: : path of the file/dir, can be in a supported protocol (lfn, srm, file, guid,..)
a list of the attribute in a string format, on after each other, separated by '\0'.
: size of the buffer

simplesect.para: return the size of the data in list , or -1 if error. In this case, errno is set and you can call gfal_posix_check_error() for a more complete description.

detaileddescription.para: Wrapper to mkdir for comptibility, same behavior than gfal_mkdirp ( but subject to change in order to follow POSIX mkdir in the futur )

briefdescription.para: open a directory

detaileddescription.para:
opens a directory to be used in subsequent gfal_readdir operations the url supported are : local files, surls, plugin url ( lfc,...)
name
of the directory to open, can be in supported protocols (lfn, srm, file, guid,..)
file descriptor DIR* if success else NULL if error and errno is set call gfal_posix_check_error() to check it

briefdescription.para: close a file descriptor of a directory similar to the POSIX call closedir close the file descriptor of an opendir call

parameterdescription.para: file handle ( return by opendir ) to close

simplesect.para: 0 if success else negativevalue and errno is set ( ( gfal_posix_error_print() )

briefdescription.para: read a directory similar to the POSIX call readdir The readdir() function returns a pointer to a dirent structure representing the next directory entry in the directory stream pointed to by dirp. It returns NULL on reaching the end of the directory stream or if an error occurred. struct dirent { ino_t d_ino; // inode number off_t d_off; // offset to the next dirent unsigned short d_reclen; // length of this record unsigned char d_type; // type of file; not supported // by all file system types char d_name[256]; // filename };

parameterdescription.para: file handle ( return by opendir ) to read

simplesect.para: pointer to struct dirent with file information or NULL if end of list or error, errno is set call gfal_posix_check_error() to check it
struct dirents are allocated statically, do not use free() on them

briefdescription.para: removes a directory if it is empty remove an existing directory, return error if the dir is not empty

parameterdescription.para: specifies the directory name, can be in supported protocols (lfn, srm, file, guid,..)

simplesect.para: return 0 is success else -1 and errno is set call gfal_posix_check_error() to check it

briefdescription.para: delete a name and possibly the file it refers to

detaileddescription.para: similar to the POSIX call unlink gfal_unlink() deletes a name from the file system. If that name was the last link to a file and no processes have the file open the file is deleted and the space it was using is made avail‐ able for reuse.
If the name was the last link to a file but any processes still have the file open the file will remain in existence until the last file descriptor referring to it is closed.
If the name referred to a symbolic link the link is removed.

If the name referred to a socket, fifo or device the name for it is removed but processes which have the object open may continue to use it.
On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set appropriately and you can call gfal_posix_check_error() for a more complete description.
clear the last error reported by a gfal posix function
Display and clear the last string error reported by the gfal error system for the posix API equivalent to a gfal_posix_print_error() and a gfal_posix_clear_error() call

Get the last Error in a string format
return a pointer to the string buffer passed.
print the last string error reported by the gfal error system for the posix API but DO NOT delete it Errors are printed on stderr

return the last error code ( ERRNO-style ) most of the error code are ERRNO codes.
last error code reported or 0 if nothing.

briefdescription.para: set the verbose mode for the current program

detaileddescription.para: set the verbose level of gfal 2
return a string of the current gfal version
